description: Enable SASL/SCRAM-SHA-256 or SASL/SCRAM-SHA-512 for client authentication. Configure sasl.mechanism and sasl.jaas.config on brokers and clients.
Implement Kerberos authentication for enterprise environments. Requires KDC setup and proper principal management.
Use OAuth 2.0 bearer tokens for authentication. Integrates with external identity providers (Okta, Azure AD, Keycloak).

Avoid SASL/PLAIN in production without TLS as the mechanism provides no credential protection beyond base64 encoding. ALWAYS pair with TLS (SASL_SSL protocol). Prefer SCRAM-SHA-256/512 which provide challenge-response authentication with salted password hashing.
Implement mutual TLS where clients present certificates signed by a trusted CA. Configure ssl.client.auth=required on brokers.
Implement regular rotation of SCRAM credentials using kafka-configs.sh. Store credentials securely in secret management systems.
Implement automated certificate rotation before expiry. Use short-lived certificates where possible. Kafka 2.5+ supports dynamic keystore/truststore updates without restart.
Configure SASL for inter-broker communication using security.inter.broker.protocol=SASL_SSL and sasl.mechanism.inter.broker.protocol.
Restrict enabled SASL mechanisms using sasl.enabled.mechanisms and listener.name.<listener>.sasl.enabled.mechanisms to only required mechanisms.
Configure ssl.principal.mapping.rules to map certificate DNs to canonical principals and prevent ambiguous identity mapping.
Use short-lived OAuth/OIDC tokens for SASL/OAUTHBEARER; validate issuer/audience and refresh tokens to reduce credential exposure.
Use unique principals and client IDs per application or tenant to support isolation, auditability, and per-tenant quotas.
Enable TLS encryption between brokers using security.inter.broker.protocol=SSL or SASL_SSL. Prevents network sniffing of replication traffic.
Configure listeners with SSL:// or SASL_SSL:// protocol. Encrypt all producer and consumer traffic.
Enable TLS for broker-to-ZooKeeper communication using zookeeper.ssl.client.enable=true.
Enable filesystem-level or disk-level encryption for Kafka log directories. Use dm-crypt, LUKS, or cloud provider encryption.
Enforce TLS 1.2 or 1.3 minimum using ssl.enabled.protocols. Disable older vulnerable protocols (SSLv3, TLS 1.0, 1.1).
Configure strong cipher suites using ssl.cipher.suites. Prioritize AEAD ciphers (GCM, ChaCha20-Poly1305).
Configure ssl.truststore with trusted CA certificates. Validate certificate chains to prevent MITM attacks.
Enable ssl.endpoint.identification.algorithm=https to verify broker hostnames match certificates.
Enable CRL/OCSP checking via JVM properties: -Dcom.sun.net.ssl.checkRevocation=true -Dcom.sun.security.enableCRLDP=true. This is JVM-level configuration, not Kafka broker configuration.
Configure ACLs to restrict topic read access using kafka-acls.sh --operation Read. Apply principle of least privilege.
Configure ACLs to restrict topic write access using kafka-acls.sh --operation Write. Prevent unauthorized data injection.
Restrict topic creation and deletion to administrators. Prevent unauthorized schema changes.
Configure ACLs for consumer group access. Restrict which consumers can join specific groups.
Restrict cluster-level operations (AlterConfigs, DescribeConfigs) to administrators only.
Configure allow.everyone.if.no.acl.found=false to deny access when no ACL matches.
Use prefixed resource patterns for scalable ACL management. Define patterns like 'myapp-*' for topic groups.
Configure ACLs for transactional producers using --transactional-id. Prevent transaction ID hijacking.
Configure ACLs for idempotent producers using IdempotentWrite operation.

Enable the ACL authorizer: ZooKeeper mode uses authorizer.class.name=kafka.security.authorizer.AclAuthorizer; KRaft mode uses authorizer.class.name=org.apache.kafka.metadata.authorizer.StandardAuthorizer.
Define super.users for break-glass administration and restrict membership to trusted identities.
Apply ACLs to internal topics (__consumer_offsets, __transaction_state, _schemas) to restrict access.
Avoid wildcard (*) ACLs in production; prefer explicit or prefixed resource patterns per team to minimize overbroad access.
Review ACLs periodically to remove unused permissions and validate least-privilege access.
Implement RBAC/ABAC policies via external authorizers or IDP claims for attribute-based access beyond static ACLs.
Enable authorizer logging to track ACL decisions. Configure log4j.logger.kafka.authorizer.logger=INFO to capture allow/deny decisions with principal, resource, and operation.
Log authentication successes and failures. Monitor for brute force attempts.
Enable request logging to track all client operations. Configure kafka.request.logger.
Configure appropriate Log4j log retention for audit compliance. Protect audit logs with restricted file permissions and forward to centralized logging.
Log and review ACL changes and dynamic config updates (AlterConfigs) and forward to SIEM.
Forward audit logs to centralized storage (Splunk, ELK, SIEM) and protect integrity with WORM storage or restricted access controls.
Audit schema registrations, compatibility changes, and deletions in Schema Registry.
Audit Kafka Connect connector create/update/pause/delete operations and task failures.
Audit consumer group offset resets/deletions and group membership changes.
Capture audit events for produce/consume/subscribe actions with principal, clientId, source IP, and outcome; store in append-only audit topics with restricted delete ACLs and extended retention.
Set replication.factor >= 3 and min.insync.replicas >= 2 on critical topics, and require producers acks=all to prevent data loss during broker failures.
Implement cross-cluster replication (MirrorMaker 2) for critical topics; enable sync.group.offsets, sync.topic.configs, and sync.topic.acls for failover readiness.
Document RTO/RPO, run periodic failover drills, and verify restore of Kafka metadata, schemas, and offsets.
Configure producer_byte_rate quota to prevent resource exhaustion from malicious or misconfigured producers.
Configure consumer_byte_rate quota to prevent denial of service through excessive consumption.
Configure request_percentage quota to limit CPU usage per client.
Configure max.connections.per.ip to prevent connection exhaustion attacks.
Set max.request.size, socket.request.max.bytes, and replica.fetch.max.bytes to cap request payloads and prevent memory exhaustion.
Set controller_mutation_rate quotas in KRaft to limit metadata changes (topic creation, ACL updates). Available in Kafka 3.0+.
Configure connection_creation_rate quotas to throttle new connections and mitigate connection storms. Available in Kafka 2.8+.
Apply per-IP quotas (entity-type ips) for producer/consumer rates to limit unauthenticated abuse.
Configure separate listeners for internal and external traffic. Use different security protocols per listener.
Configure advertised.listeners correctly to prevent exposing internal addresses externally.
Deploy Kafka in isolated network segments. Use firewall rules to restrict access to broker ports.
Remove PLAINTEXT listeners; use SSL or SASL_SSL for all listeners to prevent cleartext traffic.
Isolate sensitive data into dedicated clusters or network zones and control cross-zone data flows with sanitization pipelines.
Enable ZooKeeper ACLs using zookeeper.set.acl=true. Prevent unauthorized metadata access.
Configure SASL authentication for ZooKeeper using zookeeper.sasl.client=true.
Enable mTLS for ZooKeeper connections. Configure zookeeper.ssl.client.enable=true.
Restrict ZooKeeper 4lw commands with 4lw.commands.whitelist to reduce information exposure and unsafe operations.
Configure SASL or mTLS authentication for KRaft controllers.
Enable TLS encryption for controller-to-broker communication.
Enable authentication for Kafka Connect REST API and worker communication.
Use ConfigProvider to externalize secrets. Never store credentials in connector configs.
Secure Connect REST API access. Note: Apache Kafka Connect lacks built-in REST RBAC; requires custom RestExtension, reverse proxy with OAuth, or Confluent Platform RBAC.
Enable HTTPS for Kafka Connect REST endpoints (listeners=https://) and configure ssl.* settings.
Set connector.client.config.override.policy=None or a restrictive policy to prevent connectors from weakening security settings.
Restrict plugin.path to approved connector directories and enforce read-only permissions to prevent untrusted plugins.
Enable authentication for Schema Registry API. Use HTTPS with client certificates or bearer tokens.
Implement schema-level authorization. Restrict who can register or evolve schemas.
Enable HTTPS for Schema Registry API and secure Kafka store connection using kafkastore.security.protocol and ssl.* settings.
Set schema compatibility mode (BACKWARD/FULL/TRANSITIVE) and restrict schema deletions to prevent breaking changes.
Enable authentication and TLS for Kafka REST Proxy endpoints.
Secure MirrorMaker 2 with TLS/SASL and least-privilege ACLs on source and target clusters.
Implement application-level message encryption for sensitive data fields.
Use dedicated key management systems (HashiCorp Vault, AWS KMS) for encryption keys.
Implement data masking for sensitive fields in non-production environments.
Configure appropriate retention.ms based on data classification and compliance requirements.
Use log compaction for topics requiring data erasure capabilities (GDPR right to be forgotten).
Define data classification levels and tag events using schema metadata or Kafka headers to drive retention and access policies.
Detect PII in streams (regex/ML/schema tags) and route to quarantine or apply masking/tokenization before non-PII topics.
Redact or avoid logging message payloads containing PII in application logs, traces, and monitoring tools.
Define and enforce data contracts (schema, quality rules, ownership) for Kafka topics to prevent breaking changes.
Apply streaming data quality rules (completeness, ranges, freshness) and alert on violations to prevent bad data propagation.
Capture end-to-end data lineage for sensitive topics, schema versions, and processors to support audits and impact analysis.
Register Kafka topics, schemas, ownership, and classifications in a data catalog to support discovery and access reviews.
Apply tokenization or format-preserving encryption (FPE) for high-sensitivity fields before sharing data across zones or third parties.
Maintain regular patching schedule for Kafka brokers and client libraries. Subscribe to Kafka security mailing list and monitor CVE databases.
Remove default accounts, disable unnecessary features, and secure JMX endpoints.
Secure JMX endpoints with authentication and TLS. Restrict access to monitoring systems only.
Secure kafka-*.sh admin tools. Restrict access to authorized personnel only.
Encrypt backups of Kafka data and configurations. Secure backup storage locations.
Use config.providers to externalize sensitive configs (sasl.jaas.config, keystore/truststore passwords) from broker configs.
Run brokers as non-root and restrict filesystem permissions on log.dirs, config, keystore, and truststore files.
Set auto.create.topics.enable=false to prevent unauthorized or accidental topic creation.
Manage Kafka clusters, topics, ACLs, quotas, and connector configs via IaC/GitOps with code review and drift detection.
Configure DLQ topics and error handling for Kafka Connect and stream processors; include error context headers, retention, and ACLs for investigations.
Maintain incident response runbooks for Kafka data incidents (schema violations, lag spikes, data quality issues) and conduct postmortems.
Monitor authentication failures, ACL denials, and quota violations via JMX metrics.
Implement anomaly detection: monitor connections per client, bytes per client, offset jump detection. Use threshold-based alerts or tools like Prometheus with outlier detection.
Configure alerts for security-relevant events: auth failures, ACL changes, quota breaches.
Alert on certificate expiry and TLS handshake failures for brokers and clients.
Monitor consumer lag and lag growth rate; alert on SLA breaches for critical topics.
Alert on under-replicated partitions, offline partitions, and controller errors to detect durability risks.

Use delegation tokens for long-running applications (Kafka Streams, Spark, Flink) to avoid storing principal credentials. Configure delegation.token.master.key on brokers and manage tokens via kafka-delegation-tokens.sh.
Force periodic re-authentication using connections.max.reauth.ms to limit exposure from compromised credentials. Configure sasl.login.refresh.* on clients for credential refresh. Requires Kafka 2.2+.
Secure metadata.log.dir with restricted filesystem permissions (700). Metadata contains cluster state including ACLs and topic configurations.
Deploy minimum 3 controllers for HA. Secure controller.quorum.voters configuration and prevent unauthorized nodes from joining the quorum.
Secure Connect internal topics (config.storage.topic, offset.storage.topic, status.storage.topic) with ACLs and encryption. These contain connector configurations and credentials.
Encrypt Kafka Streams local state stores (RocksDB). Secure state.dir with filesystem permissions. State stores may contain sensitive data from processed records.
Configure security.protocol, sasl.*, and ssl.* for Kafka Streams applications. Apply least-privilege ACLs for source topics, sink topics, and internal repartition/changelog topics.
Use dynamic broker configuration (Kafka 2.5+) to update SSL keystores and truststores without restart. Enables zero-downtime certificate rotation via kafka-configs.sh --alter.
